title: 107_s1729
content: The Act is titled the "Post Terrorism Mental Health Improvement Act" and includes provisions for planning and training grants. Section 520A of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include training of mental health professionals in evidence-based practices for treating disaster victims and the development of coordinated response plans for mental health needs post-disaster. The amendment to Section 520A of the Public Health Service Act includes provisions for the development of a mental health disaster response clearinghouse and the establishment of a universal hotline for disaster assistance. States and local public entities applying for assistance must notify relevant authorities and consult with providers and organizations serving public safety officials. The amendment also defines the term 'mental health professional' to include various licensed practitioners in the mental health field. SEC. 3. Grants provided to directly affected areas for addressing long-term needs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible State and local governments and public entities to address long-term mental health needs from the 9/11 terrorist attacks. Entities must be in directly affected areas and submit an application to receive funds. Grant recipients must use the funds as specified. The grant recipients must use the funds to locate individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks needing mental health services, provide treatment for serious psychiatric illnesses resulting from the attacks, and carry out other approved activities. Funds for treatments should supplement, not replace, amounts from other programs or insurance coverage. The grant recipients must use funds to locate individuals affected by the 9/11 attacks needing mental health services, provide treatment for serious psychiatric illnesses resulting from the attacks, and carry out other approved activities. Grantees should enter into contracts with private entities and utilize existing providers to serve the affected population. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2005. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allow the Secretary to waive restrictions on supplemental funding for disaster-related scientific research projects. Additionally, a program for children experiencing violence-related stress is extended through 2005 and should be fully funded according to Congress. The Secretary, Jeri Thomson, attests.
